conclusion: Analyzing if the pedestrian can catch up with the bus based on given v-t graphs.
The pedestrian moves at a constant speed of 8 m/s (horizontal line on v-t graph).
The bus starts from rest (at origin O) and accelerates uniformly (diagonal line from origin).
At t = 8 seconds, the bus reaches a speed of 8 m/s (intersection point marked with red in the graph).
The bus acceleration is calculated as a = Δv/Δt = 8 m/s ÷ 8 s = 1 m/s².
Initial conditions: 36 meters separation, pedestrian speed 8 m/s, bus initial speed 0 m/s, bus acceleration 1 m/s².
The pedestrian's position as a function of time is x_p(t) = 8t meters.
The bus's position as a function of time is x_b(t) = 36 + 0.5t² meters.
To determine when the pedestrian catches the bus, their positions must be equal: 8t = 36 + 0.5t².
Coefficients of the quadratic equation are identified: a = 0.5, b = -8, c = 36.
The discriminant is negative (√-8), so there are no real solutions.
Final conclusion: The pedestrian cannot catch up with the bus because there is no time at which their positions are equal.
After t = 8 seconds, the bus moves at the same speed as the pedestrian (8 m/s) but is still ahead and continues to accelerate, making it impossible for the pedestrian to catch up.
